items.title: All operational US liquefied natural gas terminals have violated pollution limits, says report
bullets: • Every fully operational liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminal in the US has violated federal pollution limits in recent years, a new report has found
• The analysis of public records comes as the Trump administration is aiming to fast-track approval of new export terminals

items.title: Scientists reverse Alzheimer’s in mice with groundbreaking nanotech
bullets: • Scientists reverse Alzheimer’s in mice with groundbreaking nanotech approach
• Instead of carrying drugs, the nanoparticles themselves triggered natural clearance of amyloid-β proteins
• This restored blood-brain barrier function and reversed memory loss
• Results point to a revolutionary new path for treating neurodegenerative diseases

items.title: Found Footage Horror ‘Project Butterfly: Flatwoods’ Coming Halloween Night 2025!

• The further the students dig, the more they uncover the terrifying truths of this bunker

items.title: ‘Art is good for you’: how going to a gallery can boost your health

items.title: Climate Change Made Hurricane Melissa Four Times More Likely, Study Suggests
bullets: • A new rapid attribution study suggests human-induced climate change made the deadly tropical cyclone four times more likely
• The storm, which reached Category 5, has killed at least 40 people across the Caribbean so far
• Winds reaching speeds of 185 miles per hour and torrential rain flattened entire neighborhoods, forced more than 25,000 people to seek cover in shelters

items.title: Making KPop Demon Hunters sound magical meant finding the right harmonies
bullets: • Music is obviously a huge part of KPop Demon Hunters
• But beneath the banging soundtrack, there is a rich tapestry of sounds that each play a role in bringing the movie’s world of magic and monsters to life
• The job of crafting those sonic elements fell to Michael Babcock, a saxophonist-turned-sound designer whose past works include The First Omen, Heretic and Dune: Part Two

items.title: A contentious kids safety bill might be getting gutted — and nobody’s happy
bullets: • The Kids Online Safety Act has been a flashpoint for internet regulation for three years
• It would require web platforms to protect kids from a variety of online harms, imposing what’s known as a duty of care
• Supporters of KOSA include parents whose children have died after experiencing cyberbullying, sextortion, or obtaining illegal drugs online
